Their accounts were echoed in interviews with more than a dozen Uighurs with relatives who were in the camps or had disappeared, many of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity to avoid government retaliation.The Times also discovered reports online written by teams of Chinese officials who were assigned to monitor families with detained relatives and a 2017 study that said officials in some parts of Xinjiang were indiscriminately sending ethnic Uighurs to the camps to meet numerical quotas.The study, by Qiu Yuanyuan, a scholar at the Xinjiang Party School, where officials are trained, warned that the detentions could backfire and fan radicalism. “Recklessly setting quantitative goals for transformation through education has been erroneously used” in some areas, she wrote. “The targeting is imprecise, and the scope has been expanding.”The Xinjiang government issued “de-radicalisation” rules in 2017 that gave vague authorisation for the camps and many counties now run several of them, according to government documents, including requests for bids from construction companies to build them.In government documents, local officials sometimes liken inmates to patients requiring isolation and emergency intervention.“Anyone infected with an ideological ‘virus’ must be swiftly sent for the ‘residential care’ of transformation-through-education classes before illness arises, a document issued by party officials in Hotan said.The number of Uighurs, as well as Kazakhs and other Muslim minorities, who have been detained in the camps is unclear. title: sun bear cub debut uk first chester zoo
story: Britain&rsquos first sun bear cub makes her public debut. (Image: CHESTER ZOO)For the youngster, who has yet to be named, her start in life is far less traumatic than the ordeal her parents suffered from the evils of the illegal wildlife trade.Both Milli and mate Toni were rescued after being stolen from the wild in Cambodia when they were cubs.Having been saved and nurtured by conservationists, the bears have not only settled into their new home at Chester Zoo but also made history by producing the first sun bear cub ever to be born on British soil.Twelve weeks after her birth, the cub has emerged from her den to take a few shaky steps before the watchful eyes of enthralled visitors to the popular attraction.                Brown bears kill and EAT park ranger &ndash leaving only his bones                FINALLY FREE: Tragic bears cut from cages after YEARS of tortureTim Rowlands, Curator of Mammals at Chester Zoo, described the scenes.He said: &ldquoThe new cub has plenty of enthusiasm but, at just 12 weeks old, she&rsquos still somewhat wobbly on her legs.She&rsquoll soon find her feet though and it won&rsquot be long until mum Milli really has her paws full.&ldquoHer little one will quickly gain in confidence become more and more excitable and look to explore.That&rsquos when her parenting skills will be given a new test.We&rsquore sure she&rsquoll come through it with flying colours though &ndash she&rsquos proving to be a great mum so far.Sun bears are classed as vulnerable on the Red List of Endangered Species (Image: CHESTER ZOO)The sun bear's alternative name is honey bear (Image: CHESTER ZOO)Sun bears are not only the world&rsquos smallest of eight bear species but are also one of the most threatened.They are classed as Vulnerable on the Red List of Endangered Species and face a torrid future as their forest haunts make way for palm oil plantations and poachers hunt them down for their body parts, said to have unfounded medicinal properties.Sun bears get their name from the dazzling orange crescent markings across the chest, which legend states is a replica of the rising or setting sun.Their alternative name is the honey bear, courtesy of their habit of raiding bee nests.

story: A number of Conservative MPs called for a tougher approach, with the most popular option being to make acts of deliberate trespass a criminal offence. The new rules were referred to as the &ldquoIrish option, as it would reflect the tough stance taken towards travellers in the country.Conservative MP for Rayleigh and Wickford, Mark Francois, said during a special House of Commons debate that it would create a real deterrent that would put travellers off of moving onto land they do not own.Fellow Tory Andrew Selous, MP for South West Bedfordshire, branded the current situation &ldquoa complete disgrace and said: &ldquoMinisters and the officials responsible for this policy area should be hanging their heads in shame.He added: &ldquoThreats, violence, theft and other forms of intimidation have become everyday occurrences to some of my constituents, and Bedfordshire police, with an already overstretched budget, are not able to respond in as timely a manner as they would wish, leaving many of my constituents living in fear. A lady wrote to me in June to say that she will be moving away from the area as she no longer feels safe, having been assaulted by travellers.Council officials said the fly-tipping travellers were charging as little as &pound30 for a 3.5 ton truck (Image: NA)                Traveller family found guilty of keeping vulnerable people as slaves                Labour MP defends Gypsies during 'debate snobbery' on illegal sitesHe expressed unhappiness with current planning policy, which fails to deter &ldquomany unauthorised encampments.In 2017, there were 116 unauthorised encampments in Central Bedfordshire, and clear-up costs in the area were around &pound350,000.Sir David Amess, MP for Southend West, praised Mr Selous for &ldquonot messing about with weasel words.He added that his fellow Tory MP had &ldquotold it like it is - I agreed with everything he said, I support the Irish option.The Sunday Express revealed earlier this month that councils across the UK had been left with massive clean-up costs running into hundreds of thousands of pounds.Council officials said travellers involved in the scam were charging tradesmen and householders cut-price rates to dispose of commercial waste on the public land.Council officials said the fly-tipping travellers were charging as little as &pound30 for a 3.5 ton truckload, dumping it on land next to their caravans and then moving on and repeating the offence at another location.The problem has prompted councils across London, Essex, Surrey, Hampshire, the West Midlands and Lancashire to obtain High Court &ldquoblanket injunctions.These mean that travellers can face fines, jail or seized assets if they pull on to any land it covers.Tim Loughton, Tory MP for East Worthing and Shoreham, said yesterday: &ldquoThe real problem is that travellers will break in and cause damage to gain access to illegal encampments.&ldquoWhen they depart, they invariably leave behind a trail of devastation and rubbish, which costs the local taxpayer an enormous amount to clear up.&ldquoIs not the change in the law that we need that, rather than having to point to a single person who caused the access damage, any group of travellers illegally encamped should be collectively liable for fines and compensation, which could involve the confiscation of often quite valuable vehicles?

title: Brexit news UK EU Jacob Rees Mogg Theresa May European Union Chequers plan deal
story: Jacob Rees-Mogg claimed that he would not vote for a Brexit deal in the House of Commons if it was &ldquoa Chequers based deal.Mr Rees-Mogg, who Chairs the European Research Group, claimed has been critical of Mrs May&rsquos blueprint which he has claimed does not deliver the will of the British people.Sky News host, Jayne Secker, demanded to know why the Brexiteer would not vote for a Chequers based deal.She said: &ldquoBut, that is a deal that is representing the will of those 17million people.                Mark Carney WILL see through Brexit: Bank of England Governor to stay                Boris Johnson to &lsquothrow rocks&rsquo at Chequers Brexit plan until it breaks&ldquoAs you have said that is a deal to take the UK out of the EU and it is the best deal the Government thinks it can get.Jacob Rees-Mogg replied: &ldquoChequers doesn&rsquot take us out of the EU it leaves us subject to the acquis communautaire, the single rulebook and would leave us subject to the European Court of Justice on goods and agri-foods. So it is not a proper Brexit at all.The Sky News host then accused the Conservative MP of &ldquosupreme arrogance for claiming he would not support a Chequers based agreement.She said: &ldquoIsn&rsquot that absolute supreme arrogance if you don&rsquot mind my saying so, Sir?&ldquoI mean why do you think your version of Brexit is the only version of Brexit.&ldquoWhen you ask people why they voted to leave the EU you will get a myriad of responses.&ldquoYou will get people who said they voted ou because of EU regulation, but they haven&rsquot really thought about the implications for Northern Ireland.&ldquoOr you will get people who said they voted out for trade, but don&rsquot want customs if they are getting on the Eurostar to France.Jacob Rees-Mogg was quizzed over his Brexit ideas by Sky host Jayne Secker (Image: SKYNEWS)&ldquoSo your version of Brexit is not the only version of Brexit, you don&rsquot speak for the 17million.Mr Rees-Mogg delivered a brilliant explanation of why Chequers was not Brexit.He said: &ldquoWell, I think you have got to think what out is and what is.&ldquoPeople voted to leave the European Union and, of course, within how you leave, there are differences to how you might do that, but Chequers simply doesn&rsquot take us out of the European Union.&ldquoThat&rsquos not my version of Brexit, or anyone else version of Brexit, it&rsquos just not Brexit.&ldquoSo the question is, do you have a particular type of trade deal, how do you deal with the Northern Ireland border, to which you are absolutely right, there will be different answers, and people didn&rsquot vote for a specific vote on that.&ldquoBut they did vote to leave the European Union which Chequers fails to deliver.Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has also been very critical of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers plan since he resigned from the frontbench in July.Downing Street has claimed there is no alternative to the Chequers agreement.

title: Brexit news latest UK EU vote no deal second referendum Theresa May plan Chequers
story: The Tory MP demanded the young Remainer suggest a suitable alternative to Brexit after she hit out at the lack of clarity regarding the details of a&nbspBrexit deal.Co-founder of campaign group Our Future, Our Choice Lara Spirit told BBC&rsquos Politics Live: &ldquoThe tone of this is toxic and I do think that it is inhibiting constructive debate about this.&ldquoBut what I would say is that this idea that we don&rsquot know now and we are going to know when Parliament comes to vote on this deal is completely wrong.&ldquoWhat we are going to see is a fudge deal. We are going to see a blind Brexit and we are going to go into the transition deal with no idea what Brexit still means.                Rees-Mogg accussed of 'supreme arrogance' - watch his STUNNING replyBut as the Tory MP demanded the&nbspRemainer&nbspcome up with a solution, BBC host Jo Coburn attempted to intervene.&nbspMr Afolami grilled the Remainer and said: &ldquoAlright then. What&rsquos good enough? Tell me what&rsquos good enough. What would you sign up to?Ms Spirit swerved the question and instead continued her plea for a second Brexit referendum. She said: &ldquoAt the moment, I think the idea that you can have frictionless trade and also control of your borders &ndash it&rsquos just incompatible.&ldquoLook, I voted Remain. I do want to Remain in the&nbspEuropean Union. I do want to Remain in the European Union.Brexit news: Tory MP Bim Afolami hit back at calls for a so-called 'People's Vote' (Image: BBC)&ldquoBut I also think that many people who voted to leave the European Union who might look at this and think that it is a disaster and might want to change their minds should be given the opportunity to do so. I think a people&rsquos vote is the only way of doing that.Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos Brexit plan, calling for close regulatory alignment with the EU&rsquos single market for British exports, has faced scrutiny from both Brexiteers and Remainers.The proposal includes plans to create a common rule book &ndash involving a free trade area with the EU on industrial and agricultural goods.The Brexit plan has been heavily criticised by former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson since the Tory MP for Uxbridge and South Ruislip resigned over the agreement in July.On Sunday, Boris Johnson wrote that Mrs May was wrapping a &ldquosuicide vest around a &ldquogreat British Brexit.But Mrs May has so far vowed to stick by her controversial Brexit blueprint.The EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has previously rejected Mrs May&rsquos plans and ruled out any special economic relationship with the UK &ndash claiming it would unravel the entire &ldquoEuropean project.But in a shock u-turn, Mr Barnier told a forum in Slovenia on Monday it is realistic to expect a orce deal with Britain in six to eight weeks &ndash suggesting the orce could be settled by the week beginning October 15 &ndash just in time for the EU Summit on October 18.The EU chief negotiator said: I think that if we are realistic we are able to reach an agreement on the first stage of the negotiation, which is the Brexit treaty, within 6 or 8 weeks.Taking into account the time necessary for the ratification process, the House of Commons on one side, the European Parliament and the Council on the other side&hellip We must reach an agreement before the beginning of November. I think it is possible.

title: Brexit news UK Jacob Rees Mogg UK latest EU no deal Mark Carney Bank of England
story: The prominent Brexiteer took a huge swipe at Mark Carney&rsquos decision to extend his role and said his decision to &ldquopoliticise the role will ultimately &ldquoreflect poorly on him.Mr Carney, who was appointed as governor in 2013, had already agreed to prolong his mandate for one year in the wake of the EU referendum, in June 2016.But it was announced on Tuesday that the Bank of England boss will continue his role until January 2020 in order to &ldquosupport a smooth and successful Brexit.Following the announcement, Mr Rees-Mogg told Sky News: &ldquoI think it&rsquos a pity that he has played ducks and drakes with his term of appointment.                'Time is RUNNING OUT&rsquo to strike Brexit deal warns Philip Hammond&nbsp&ldquoIt was meant to be eight years &ndash he said for family reasons he could only do five years.&ldquoThen he extended it and now he has extended it again. I think the governorship of the Bank of England is too important a post to have been politicised as, sadly, he has done.&ldquoOr to be muddled about in this way. I think it is very undignified and reflect poorly on him.Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond confirmed Mr Carney will stay on until January 2020 during Treasury Questions at the House of Commons this morning.Brexit news: Jacob Rees-Mogg calls Mark Carney's decision undignified  (Image: BBC&bullBank of England)The Canadian will remain in his role until 31 January, 2020 after Mr Hammond and the Prime Minister asked him to extend his term &ldquoto support a smooth exit of the UK from the EU and an effective transition to the next Governor.Mr Carney said: It is important that everyone does everything they can to support a smooth and successful Brexit.A spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said the Prime Minister believes Mr Carney has been doing a good job but others branded the decision to extend Mr Carney's term was appalling.Nigel Farage&nbspsaid: &ldquoTruly appalling decision to extend Mark Carney&rsquos term at the Bank of England. He is a&nbspRemainer, how can we take this government seriously?Mr Carney was asked last week by Treasury committee&rsquos Charlie Elphicke if there would be cheaper food under World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules.After a series of grillings on the issue, the banking boss refused to answer because he said his comments influence the sterling.Mr Carney said: &ldquoNo. It depends. And it depends on where the exchange rate goes because it is the net of the tariffs.He added: &ldquoIt&rsquos true in terms of the tariff component of it if that is the choice. But the exchange rate determination is on the broader economic forces.&ldquoAnd it depends on how much the exchange rate moves which would be a function of a variety of factors around the nature of the exit and other arrangements.&ldquoBut, certainly, if you want to take option prices and financial market skews and others the expectation would be, in financial markets at present, the expectation of a no deal and no transitional scenario is that there would be another, for a period of time, downward movement in sterling.When asked how much, Mr Carney said: &ldquoOnce I say it has more currency, if you will.

title: scotland news ambulance strike UNITE SNP
story: Furious ambulance crews could go on strike  (Image: )Leaders of the Unite union today lambasted dangerously long working hours in the Scottish Ambulance Service (SAS) north ision.It said an employee had worked three times the 12 hour shift while another had been on duty for 23 hours.Workers including paramedics, ambulance technicians, drivers and call centre staff will now take part in a consultative ballot on industrial action.Last year Unite lodged an official dispute with management over the service provided to the public in the ision, which covers the Highlands and Islands and Grampian.                Nicola Sturgeon accused of &lsquofailing&rsquo patients due to bed delays                SNP accused of 'STOCKPILING GRIEVANCE' over BrexitThe union's regional officer Tommy Campbell said it was a national scandal that some were working such long hours, claiming paramedics are being exploited.He warned extreme shifts overruns can cause stress and tiredness amongst workers, adding that excessive vacancies are leading to staff having to work overtime.Mr Campbell added: This is unfortunately not an unusual incident and there are many other examples of paramedics working dangerously long hours.Unite members in their determination to serve the public have had their goodwill and dedication exploited.Miles Briggs urged SNP ministers to act now to prevent excessive long hours (Image: SCOTTISH PARLIAMENT)For this reason, Unite will now move to a consultative ballot on industrial action which we hope focuses the minds of Scottish Ambulance Service management.A survey of ambulance workers in Scotland carried out by Unite in 2017 found more than half (54.3 per cent) were suffering from stress.As well as this 94.5 per cent said morale in the force had worsened, with 91.4 per cent warning staffing levels were insufficient and 90.4 per cent complaining of fatigue.Unite previously raised concerns over a lack of ambulances to respond to 999 calls, staff regularly working over scheduled hours and fatigue among workers in the north ision.                Disabled out-patient chased for &ldquodebt after NHS parking blunder                 Sturgeon rejects Scottish farmers' pleas to back May's Brexit plansIt is also claimed that emergency cover in Aberdeen has led to crews being shifted from other areas, creating shortage of cover in rural areas.Scottish Tory health spokesman Miles Briggs urged SNP ministers to act now to prevent excessive long hours.He added: The priority here is to resolve this dispute without any threat of industrial action &ndash that would prove to be more dangerous than anything.There are clearly staffing issues right across Scotland, and these specific examples &ndash if true &ndash would be completely unacceptable.Workers right across the health service are suffering because of SNP mismanagement and its disastrous workforce planning.A Scottish Government spokesman said: &ldquoNHS staff welfare is critically important and we have well recognised, long standing and positive partnership arrangements in place with staff and their representatives.&ldquoWe appreciate the particular pressures in this region and expect the Scottish Ambulance Service and Unite to continue to work together to reach a constructive resolution to the issues that have been raised.

story: Chrissie Hynde said the construction site distracted her during her set (Image: NC)The musician, who played at Dundee&rsquos waterfront on Sunday, said the construction site distracted her during her set.The &pound15.1million block has been criticised for obstructing views of the museum, and Hynde, 67, said there should be &ldquosome sort of uprising against it.The American singer &ndash once married to Simple Minds star Jim Kerr &ndash said: &ldquoIn the daylight I noticed this quite beautiful building in the background, which I didn&rsquot realise is the V&ampA building, and this horrible carcass going up in front of it.&ldquoI did mention that, because it was actually distracting me from what I was trying to do.                'Save our gig venues' Paul McCartney and celeb pals lobby parliament                Rock legends Chrissie Hynde and Jim Kerr to reunite on stage &ldquoI have been walking around Dundee and I was walking down Union Street there and I saw the V&ampA again, a really beautiful vista of it, and this monstrosity that&rsquos totally obliterating the view of that beautiful building. Why should it be obliterating a beautiful new initiative to bring people into the city?&ldquoPut it somewhere else. I would have it torn down. There should be some sort of uprising against it.But Dundee City Council leader John Alexander said it made &ldquolittle economic sense to leave the site of the office block empty.He added: &ldquoFrom the start, the council and its partners have been absolutely clear that the waterfront was created not only as a place for fun and creativity, but more importantly as a place where we could generate jobs and income for the people of Dundee. That plan is bearing fruit.The &pound15.1million block has been criticised for obstructing views of the museum (Image: NC)V&ampA architect Kengo Kuma has also backed the development (Image: NC)&ldquoThese proposals have been under way since I was nine years of age. This has not happened overnight.&ldquoThis is part of a longer term, sustainable, more prosperous and exciting future for the city.V&ampA architect Kengo Kuma has also backed the development.He said earlier this year: &ldquoMy building was always designed to complement and harmonise with its surroundings and adjacent developments. It was never designed in isolation and was always meant to be part of a built environment.

title: scotland news st andrews scientists children apes
story: Scientists were surprised by how many similarities they found (Image: NCADRIAN SOLDATI)The study, led by the University of St Andrews, found that children aged one to two use 52 gestures, more than 95 per cent of which are shared with the great apes.Experts studied chimpanzees in a natural habitat, the Budongo Forest in Uganda, and observed young children in their nurseries and at home.It was the first time in more than 20 years of studying great ape communication that the scientists had also studied young humans &ndash and they were surprised by how many similarities they found.The senior author of the study, Dr Catherine Hobaiter of the School of Psychology and Neuroscience at St Andrews, said: &ldquoWild chimpanzees, gorillas, bonobos and orang-utans all use gestures to communicate, but until now there was always one ape missing from the picture &ndash us.                Judy Murray blasts lack of tennis courts in Glasgow                Chrissie Hynde slams office block next to V&ampA Dundee&ldquoWe used exactly the same approach to study young chimpanzees and children, which makes sense. Children are just tiny apes.Wild apes have been found to use more than 80 different gestures to say things like &ldquocome here, &ldquoI want that, &ldquocome with me or even &ldquogo away. The scientists have written a &ldquogreat ape dictionary of what each gesture means.The team, which also included scientists from Switzerland and Germany, found that human children used the gestures in a similar way, combining them to ask for different things.But young humans used pointing gestures far more than young apes, and waving hello or goodbye seems uniquely human.Dr Hobaiter said: &ldquoWe thought we might find a few of these gestures &ndash reaching out your palm to ask for something or sticking your hand up in the air &ndash but we were amazed to see so many &lsquoape&rsquo gestures used by the children.The findings suggest that the gestures may have a very old evolutionary origin.Another scientist who worked on the study, Dr Verena Kersken, of the University of G&oumlttingen in Germany, added: &ldquoSince chimpanzees and humans shared a common ancestor five to six million years ago, we wanted to know whether our evolutionary history of communication is also reflected in human development.While humans developed language, it appears that we still have access to these ancient gestures &ndash and that they are still important for our children before their language is fully developed.The study, &ldquoA Gestural Repertoire of One to Two-year-old Human Children: In Search of the Ape Gestures, is published in the journal Animal Cognition.

story: Unemployment fell by by 55,000 over the period to 1.36 million, giving a jobless rate of 4 per cent (Image: pbombaert)Meanwhile employment increased by 3,000 in the three months to July to 32.4 million, giving a rate of 75.5 per cent, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS) .It came as unemployment fell by by 55,000 over the period to 1.36 million, giving a jobless rate of 4 per cent.Job vacancies, meanwhile, rose 14,000 on quarter to 833,000, a record high.The Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, Esther McVey, said: Since 2010 we have delivered significant growth in jobs, and in the last six months we've seen real terms wage growth.We haven't had a lower unemployment rate for over forty years and I'm especially proud that youth unemployment is at a record low, falling by over 45 per cent since 2010 - opening up career opportunities for our next generation.                EU CRISIS: No-deal Brexit would spark financial &lsquoTURMOIL&rsquo for Europe                BREXIT BREAKTHROUGH: Rees-Mogg reveals SOLUTION to Irish border issueIn the EU we see unemployment rates over double those of the UK. This Government is transforming this country into a great working nation. Ready and prepared for the future challenges after Brexit.Samuel Tombs, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said: Signs that employment growth is slowing should mean that the MPC (Monetary Policy Committee) does not feel compelled to dampen the recent upturn in wage growth by raising interest rates again soon.He said wage growth data was also linked to a recent pay rise for nearly 1.3 NHS workers , which pushed up public sector pay.While private sector wages also grew, he said the underlying trend still looks fairly flat.Wage growth in the private sector likely will struggle to pick up further, given that the job market still has some slack and employees remain less willing than usual to move jobs.As a result, the MPC should be able to stick to its plans for only gradual increases in bank rate over the coming years.The good economic news came as the Department for International Trade prepares to unveil a new partnership between Britain and the Texas Medical Center (TMC), home to 61 world leading innovators, including the US&rsquo leading cancer hospital, will now offer UK companies a unique package which will help boost exports and drive forward scientific innovation.It gives British scientists access to the US&rsquo $3.3 trillion medical market and research in a move which should allow the UK to be a major world player after Brexit.Former government Chief Scientist, and current Chief Executive of UK Research and Innovation, Sir Mark Walport, said: &ldquoThis unique opportunity will prove to be a valuable asset to UK and US healthcare professionals who are working tirelessly on the advancement of medical treatments for people all over the world.&ldquoWith the recognition of the UK as a leader in research and development, I hope to see further collaboration between the Texas Medical Center and the UK in the near future.

title: thread free tv licenses over 75
story: TV provides companionship for many OAPs (Image: Getty ImagesWestend61)It was previously compensated by the Department for Work and Pensions but this repayment is being phased out.&nbspThe BBC will foot the whole bill from 2020 when it is set to cost about &pound725million a year.&nbspDirector-general Lord Hall yesterday stopped short of confirming to MPs that elderly viewers will continue to receive the licence free of charge.&nbspHe told the Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee: &ldquoThe concession, as it is currently formulated, comes to an end in June 2020. That was part of the last licence fee settlement. We, the board, have got to decide what to replace it with.&nbsp&ldquoWe have got to be mindful, we know that those over 65 or over 75 consume many, many more BBC services than others. There is real hardship among some or many of those over 75 too. It could be the same. The board could say, we will just continue with it as it is. It could be reformed. There&rsquos a whole load of options.&nbsp                BBC presenter Dan Walker bemoans licence payers knowing what he earns                BBC warns free TV licence for over-75s to be reviewed&ldquoWe are just not in a position to say what the right option will be. We have got to have a public consultation about what we do.&nbspHe added: &ldquoWe will make a decision in the autumn or winter.&nbspCurrently such people do not automatically become exempt but can apply for a licence waiver online or by post.&nbspThe cost represents nearly 14 per cent of the BBC&rsquos &pound5.06billion annual income.&nbspIt has previously been suggested that the benefit could be means-tested.&nbspAnother option would be to stop giving free licences to people who live with someone who is not eligible for the benefit. Caroline Abrahams, director of the charity Age UK, said: &ldquoIncreasing numbers of older people who live alone say their main form of companionship is their TV and for many others, especially those who are housebound, TV is a precious window on to the world.&nbsp&ldquoAnything that makes it harder for older people like these to enjoy watching TV would be a source of great concern to Age UK.&nbspA BBC spokesman said it was obliged to consult on what the policy would be from 2020 as part of its charter renewal.&nbspLord Hall admitted the BBC &ldquooverdid it with its coverage of a police raid on 77-year-old pop star Sir Cliff Richard&rsquos home.&nbspThe broadcaster decided not to pursue an appeal against a judge&rsquos ruling over its coverage of the event after the star won damages for invasion of privacy.

title: Brexit news Michael Gove EU exit UK farmers countryside agriculture environment
story: &ldquoIt will help them grow more high quality food in a more sustainable way (Image:  )Mr Gove has stated that Brexit will allow the UK to take better care of its natural environment, provide additional assistance to farmers and cut bureaucratic costs linked to the European Union&rsquos Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).Commenting on the Government&rsquos new Agriculture Bill, due to be published today, he told The : &ldquoIt will reward farmers properly at last for the work they do to enhance the environment around us.&ldquoIt will help them grow more high quality food in a more sustainable way.&ldquoAnd it will ensure public money is spent more efficiently and effectively.                BREXIT BOOM as earnings RISE and unemployment DROPS                 Boris slams May&rsquos plan as &lsquoworse than staying in the EU&rsquoAround 70 percent of UK land is managed by farmers, with 475,000 employed in the sector according to the National Farmers Union (NFU).Mr Gove claimed the Government&rsquos Bill will &ldquosupport farmers in getting a decent price for the food they produce and clamp down on &ldquounfair trading practices along the supply chain.He added that once we leave the EU, &ldquowe can ensure we devote public money to enriching wildlife habitats, preventing flooding, improving the quality of air and help manage and mitigate the effects of climate change.Mr Gove was fiercely critical of the CAP, the EU&rsquos current agricultural programme, saying: &ldquoWhilst we have been subject to the rules of the CAP our environment has suffered.It will ensure public money is spent more efficiently and effectively (Image:  )&ldquoValuable habitats have been lost, the number of farmland birds has dropped and the health of the soil has been eroded.&ldquoThe complex rules governing this process have inhibited innovation and added bureaucratic costs to food production.The CAP imposes a system of agricultural subsidies across the EU, at a cost of nearly 40 percent of the bloc&rsquos annual budget.It has long been criticised in the UK by eurosceptics, who argue it encourages overproduction and is wasteful. title: 5 star cafe that money cannot buy
story: Kevin Baker, 54, and his wife Laura, 34, who run the Nice Baps cafe near Wadebridge, Cornwall (Image: James Dadzitis SWNS)Kevin serves all-day breakfasts to hungry travellers from a shipping container decorated to look like a log cabin in a lay-by. The cafe has won a huge following and become the highest rated of 2,218 eateries in Cornwall on review site TripAdvisor. The business has been granted a permanent trading licence and caught the eye of the coffee giant, which was recently bought by Coca-Cola for &pound3.9billion.&nbspKevin said: &ldquoCosta Coffee wanted to buy us out. They came to us three times and on the third time they offered us &pound120,000 to move but I refused. I said you can offer us &pound1million but we are staying.&nbspNice Baps, in Wadebridge, has been on TripAdvisor for 10 months, in which time it has received nothing but five-star reviews.&nbsp                Rise and shine: Six of the best healthy breakfast recipes                Batch, Bap or Bridie? Brits just can't decide what to call the...Kevin has become a &ldquolegend and gets as many mentions as the food, which has been dubbed a &ldquomasterclass in the fine art of an all-day breakfast.&nbspNice Baps has also attracted celebrity customers including former Prime Minister David Cameron, former EastEnders actor Joe Absolom and the cast of Poldark.&nbspFather-of-two Kevin says the secret to their success is providing a good service, cheap food and having fun and treating people well.He added: &ldquoRemember where you have come from and treat others as you want to be treated and people will come back to you.&nbsp&ldquoWe are giving customers a little bit of what people need these days &ndash comfort and a friendly face. If a family turns up after a long journey, we occupy the kids with magic tricks to give the parents a break.&nbspPatrons enjoy their breakfast at The Nice Baps cafe near Wadebridge, Cornwall  (Image: James Dadzitis SWNS&#8232)&ldquoOld people come in because they need someone to talk to. It&rsquos an escape for them.&nbspOne reviewer wrote: &ldquoThis place doesn&rsquot just have Nice Baps, it has the biggest, juiciest, most flavoursome baps I&rsquove ever tasted (other food is available).&nbsp&ldquoIf I could afford to drive to Cornwall every day to have breakfast here, I most definitely would.&nbspAnother reviewer said simply: &ldquoBest Kevin Baker and wife Laura in front of roadside cafe Nice Baps. story: Hurricane Florence is expected to make landfall in the south-east or mid-Atlantic region of the US on Thursday night or Friday morning.South Carolina, North Carolina and Virginia are forecast to take the worst of the initial hit, with all three states declaring states of emergency and ordering mandatory evacuations.The barreling storm with winds of more than 140 mph is expected to become a Category 5 hurricane later this week.Follow us below for all the live updates and latest news on Hurricane Florence's path. These observations suggest that an eyewall replacement cycle is likely underway.Florence's upper-level environment is predicted to remain quite favorable while the storm traverses sea surface temperatures of around 29C over the next 48 hours.Additional strengthening is forecast during this time, but some fluctuations in intensity are likely due to eyewall replacement cycles.The updated NHC intensity forecast once again calls for additional intensification and brings Florence to near category 5 strength within the next 24 to 36 hours.After 48 hours, a slight increase in southwesterly shear could result in some weakening, but Florence is expected to remain an extremely dangerous hurricane when it approaches the U.S. coastline.10.00am update: Latest NOAA and NHC warnings now outA Storm Surge Watch is in effect for:Edisto Beach South Carolina to the North Carolina-Virginia borderAlbemarle and Pamlico Sounds, including the Neuse and Pamlico RiversA Hurricane Watch is in effect for:Edisto Beach South Carolina to the North Carolina-Virginia borderAlbemarle and Pamlico SoundsHurricane Florence satellite map: Florence is tracking towards land (Image: WXCHARTS)9.41am update:&nbspThis week marks the peak of the Atlantic hurricane seasonThree major storms are currently spinning at the same time - only&nbspthe eleventh time on record that three hurricanes have been active at the same time in the Atlantic.Hurricane Florence is due to be upgraded to a category 5 hurricane at any moment, as it barrels towards the Carolinas and Virginia.But there is also Isaac and Helen to watch out for.Find out more about the latest hurricanes in the Atlantic here.9.20am update: Residents begin packing up their belongings amid extending evacuation ordersHolden Beach, North Carolina, is directly in the barreling&nbsphurricane's path and longtime residents are busy securing their homes and possessions.It's scary to all of us. title: brexit news germany economy hard brexit latest wolfgang munchau
story: Wolfgang M&uumlnchau said the likelihood of the UK leaving the European Union without a deal &ldquohas risen dramatically in recent months and those in Germany urging the bloc maintain its tough negotiating stance are &ldquoturkeys voting for Christmas.The prominent financial commentator warned Germany&rsquos annual &pound44.5billion (&euro50billion) trade surplus with Britain means a hard Brexit would be &ldquodisastrous for the EU powerhouse.And he said Angela Merkel&rsquos government should stop opposing Britain&rsquos exit for political reasons and focus ensuring a deal on trade is struck to protect the German economy.Writing in German newspaper Handelsblatt, he said: &ldquoA hard Brexit would not only be a first-degree disaster for German industry.                Rees-Mogg claims he has 'ONE ambition' - that is to deliver Brexit                Boris Johnson to &lsquothrow rocks&rsquo at Chequers Brexit plan until it breaks&ldquoMoreover, a hard Brexit would have more serious consequences for the German economy than a trade war with the US.&ldquoAn agreement that guarantees the free movement of goods is not as good as a full membership, but much better than no deal.&ldquoIt is therefore irrational, from the perspective of the German economy, to support a policy that increases the risk of a hard Brexit.Mr M&uumlnchau identified the Irish border issue as the biggest obstacle to securing a Brexit deal.Brexit news: Germany would face economic 'disaster' from a hard Brexit, an economic commentator says (Image: )Angela Merkel's government should be pushing to ensure the UK gets a Brexit deal, Mr M&uumlnchau said (Image: REUTERS)                Germany 'needs 400,000 workers' from overseas to plug HUGE labour gap                Brexit does not scare German bank who will keep THOUSANDS in UK The EU has proposed a contingency which would kick in to prevent a hard border if no other deal is reached.The so-called &lsquobackstop&rsquo plan would see Northern Ireland stay in the customs union and most of the single market, removing the need for customs checks between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.But Theresa May has already rejected this proposal, arguing it would effectively create a border in the Irish Sea and risk the break-up of the United Kingdom.The Prime Minister is instead pushing for a &lsquofacilitated customs agreement&rsquo which would see the whole of the UK largely aligned with the EU on customs rules and tariff in a bid to keep trade as frictionless as possible.Germany's booming economy is running a &pound44.5bn annual trade surplus with the UK (Image:  IMAGES)Mrs May&rsquos plans have been met with a frosty reception from Brussels which has warned the proposals could threaten the integrity of the single market.But Mr M&uumlnchau said the best Brexit outcome Germany can hope for is a deal based on Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals which would mitigate damage on the trade of goods.He said: &ldquoThe proposal is not so bad from the point of view of the German industry. The duty-free movement of goods is maintained.&ldquoThe argument that this would destroy the single market is a massive distortion.&ldquoThe single market, its rules and its arbitration mechanisms remain in force.&ldquoOf the Brexit positions in the UK, Prime Minister May's opinion is the best from a German perspective - or at least good enough.&ldquoShe wants to protect the goods trade, and wants close cooperation with the EU for security policy.&ldquoAnyone who continues to argue for a tough stance on the British government in view of the current political situation in the UK either does not have the economic interests of Germany in mind or behaves like turkeys who express themselves without full information, but with a great enthusiasm for Christmas.Additional reporting by Monkia Pallenberg.

title: uk weather forecast latest met office forecast hurricane tropical storm helene
story: Gales and torrential downpours threaten to hammer swathes of the country early next week if Helene makes a direct hit on the UK.However the tropical storm could narrowly swerve the country and instead supercharge a sweltering blast of heat already poised to send thermometers rocketing towards 30C (86F).Helene&rsquos path and impact will depend on whether she collides with the jet stream over the coming days and the atmospheric conditions over Britain after the weekend, experts say.Some early weather models predict furious winds whipped up by a deep low-pressure system associated with the hurricane will pummel the nation.Helene is one of three &lsquolife-threatening&rsquo storms churning the Atlantic with Isaac and Florence about to unleash a deadly assault on the American continent.Hurricane Florence is on course to smash the eastern United States on Sunday with Tropical Storm Isaac expected to make landfall on the Dominican Republic around the same time.Helene is forecast to make a u-turn away from America at the end of this week before hurtling towards the UK.                UK weather forecast: Britain braces for FIERCE STORM and TORNADOES                UK weather forecast SHOCK: Early winter FREEZE to blast Britain Met Office meteorologist Emma Smith said: &ldquoThere is a chance Helene will be caught up in the jet stream and that would bring some wet and windy weather to the UK after the weekend.&ldquoHowever this will depend on the conditions around the UK at the time of arrival, it could end up strengthening high pressure emphasising drier conditions.The remnants of the storm could supercharge a burst of warm air already set to sweep into southeastern Britain this weekend.Temperatures are tipped to reach 25C (77F) across East Anglia, Kent, Essex and and London on Sunday with highs in the mid-20Cs forecast into next week.The remains of Helene are expected to nudge thermometers even higher brining a freakishly warm spell of weather to southern Britain.Miss Smith added: &ldquoThere is a chance the southeast could turn very warm next week and this could be another effect of the remnants of Helene.&ldquoAlready we expect temperatures in the region to be higher than average for the time of year due to the direction of airflow bringing warmer air in from the Atlantic.&ldquoAir associated with Helene could end up being caught up with this bringing even warmer conditions.Helene, a category-2 hurricane with wind speeds topping 110mph, is currently hurtling north-westwards across the Atlantic.UK weather forecast: Hurricane Helene could strike Britain (Image: NETWEATHER)It is forecast to switch direction and take a north-eastward path towards the UK on Friday before reaching British shores early next week.Wind speeds should drop to around 70mph as Helene is downgraded to a tropical storm on its track towards western Europe.However she is expected to strengthen over the next few days as she feeds on warm, moist air over the Atlantic.A spokesman for the US National Hurricane Centre said: &ldquoThere still appears to be a small window of opportunity for Helene to strengthen, during the next 12 hours or so.&ldquoGlobal models show Helene either maintaining tropical storm strength or even intensifying by the end of the period, possibly due to some mid-latitude dynamic forcing influences.&ldquoA turn more toward the northwest is forecast early on Wednesday Helene should slowly turn northward and then north-northeastward during the next 72 to 96 hours, followed by a turn toward the northeast.&ldquoIt&rsquos also worth noting that the Florida State Cyclone Phase Evolution analysis and forecast product shows the system retaining a relatively symmetric warm core through the entire forecast.UK weather forecast: Hurricane Helene could 'hitch a ride' on the jet stream to Britain (Image: WXCHARTS)More than a million people have evacuated their North and South Carolina homes as monster storm Florence rampages towards the United States.The category-4 hurricane is due to smash into North America on Thursday and could be the most powerful to hit the region in 30 years.Florence threatens to unleash devastating near-150mph winds with torrential rainfall raising fears floods could leave thousands homeless.Tropical Storm Isaac poses less of a threat although its increasing wind speeds have put parts of the Caribbean on alert for impact later this week.The three-storm attack follows warnings this autumn could bring increased tropical cyclone activity in the Atlantic although this number forming at the same time is unusual.Some spaghetti models show the trio converging in the middle of the ocean over the next few days spawning a giant mega-hurricane.However the most likely outcome is that Florence hits the eastern United States as Issac smashes Central America while Helene veers towards Europe and the UK.UK weather forecast: A spaghetti model showing Hurricane Helene reaching Britain (Image: CYCLOCANE)The journey of the storm will be guided by a powerful jet stream acting like a conveyor belt between the Atlantic and the United Kingdom.Unusually high wind speeds and the meandering nature of the rapidly-flowing ribbon of air high in the atmosphere are to blame, experts say.Piers Corbyn, forecaster for WeatherAction, said a blast of tropical air could push temperatures to 28C (82.4F) in the south next week.He said: &ldquoThere is going to be a general increase in temperatures across parts of the country next week and this is due to the jet stream going through a phase of wild deviations due to lower solar activity.&ldquoThe jet stream is currently stronger and faster than usual and is much wavier meaning it dips and sweeps across its path.&ldquoWe expect it to bring a plume of air in from the south, this will have originated from Africa and the Continent, but with the addition of warm air brought in by Helene temperatures could rise very high in parts.&ldquoWe would not be surprised to see 27C (80.6F) or 28C (82.4F) next week.The weather across the world is getting wilder and weirder, causing chaos, death and destruction around the globe.                     Caters News Agency1 of 96These frightening photos of lightning from a hurricane above Miami, Florida in the USA were taken after the storm left a trail of destruction in the Caribbean. Britain&rsquos weather is due to turn more unsettled through the coming days with northern regions on alert for heavy rain and wind.The Met Office&rsquos Emma Smith said: &ldquoThe jet stream is across the UK bringing outbreaks of rain for most of England and Wales from Tuesday night into Wednesday.&ldquoBy Wednesday afternoon the rain will be largely confined to the south coast with much of the country remaining dry and bright.&ldquoOn Thursday we will start to see windy weather coming into the north eighty further outbreaks of rain and again on Friday low pressure to the north of the country will bring more showery outbreaks across much of the country.Saturday will bring widespread showery outbreaks with more prolonged rainfall forecast for Sunday, she said.The Weather Company&rsquos Katie Greening added: &ldquoAn unsettled south-westerly to westerly flow will bring unsettled conditions to many areas through this week.&ldquoMore especially across the west and north where rain will be persistent at times.&ldquoRain will be lighter and more patchy to the south and east with more sunshine in these areas.&ldquoIt'll turn notably fresher from Wednesday, with temperatures falling slightly below normal.

title: Hurricane Florence path update NOAA weather latest North South Carolina tracker
story: Hurricane Florence is set to smash into the coast of North Carolina and South Carolina on Thursday or Friday.NOAA Hurricane Hunter flight director Paul Flaherty, who has been surveying the storm, warned that residents must flee from the category four storm, which is expected to unleash devastating winds and destructive flooding in the eastern Carolinas this week.Mandatory evacuation orders have been issued for more than 1 million people in coastal areas of the Carolinas and Virginia.THE NOAA boss told CNN: &ldquoIt is very very dangerous. This is life-threatening.                Hurricane Florence: Full list of affected cruise routes&ldquoOne of the things is we come out here and we do everything we can and want to make sure that we get the best data going to the National Hurricane Center in the models and to the media so we can get people out of the way because it is a life-threatening situation and every time there is going to be those people who decide to stay.The hurricane expert warned that the storm is likely to strengthen even more before it makes landfall.He said: &ldquoBut people have to know that forecast of this thing coming to the US as a major category four, potentially category five storm, this is extremely important and they need to be paying attention.Mr Flaherty explained the moment he saw the eyewall of the hurricane forming. He said: &ldquoWe were watching it develop and you just have this sick feeling in your gut.Hurricane Florence: NOAA warn of life threatening conditions (Image: NOAA&bullCBS)He added: &ldquoIt just kind of hits you in the gut when you see this thing strengthening to know that the forecast is calling for it to come in as such a strong storm.&ldquoSo we don&rsquot like what we are seeing. I don&rsquot think you guy like much what you are seeing on the ground either.Hurricane Florence has potential to cause massive damage to the US southern east coast and mid-Atlantic.AccuWeather Vice President of Forecasting and Graphics Operations Marshall Moss said: &ldquoThere&rsquos never been a storm like Florence.&ldquoIt was located farther north in the Atlantic than any other storm to ever hit the Carolinas, so what we&rsquore forecasting is unprecedented.According to the&nbspNational Hurricane Centre (NHC), tropical-storm-force winds could arrive on the US East Coast late Wednesday earliest.However, the most likely time is Thursday morning and the NHC urges people to use Wednesday as the absolutely last day to prepare for the storm.Florence is heading for the coast at 15mph and is preparing to smash the US with maximum sustained winds up to 130 mph.The NHC expects the storm to be a Category 5 in the next 24 to 36 hours, before it makes landfall at some point on Thursday.

Then we add in some other concerns as well, in terms of rain and wind.In South Carolina, Governor Henry McMaster ordered more than 1 million residents along his state's coastline to leave starting at noon local (5pm&nbspBST) time on Tuesday.North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia and Maryland governors have declared states of emergency.The CBS News forecaster added: &ldquoBut the storm surge is that big concern up into the Neuse River into New Bern &ndash that the New River into Jacksonville, parts of the Albemarle Sound going up into parts of Plymouth and Washington &ndash that&rsquos miles away from the coastline.Hurricane Florence: NOAA map shows storm hitting the US mainland on Thursday (Image: NOAA)&ldquoSo, it is not just if you are on one of those barrier islands. It&rsquos also if you are on any of those interior things. Because here is the problem, you are going to get the winds continuing to just pile water into all of these back bays and you&rsquore going to get that for a long period of time.He added: &ldquoIt is going to be a catastrophic flooding situation and that is just from the storm surge and not even talking about the rain.In the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration&rsquos (NOAA) advisory, hurricane Florence is reportedly getting better organised and increasing in size.In the update, published 2pm AST (7pm BST) the major hurricane was located about 845 miles east-southeast of North Carolina.The storm is creeping closer at 17mph, an increased speed from previous forecasts.Maximum sustained winds are at 130mph with higher speed in some wind gusts makes Florence a Category 4 hurricane.NOAA&rsquos advisory also states that the southeastern and mid-Atlantic states should monitor the progress of Hurricane Florence closely as addition watches may be issued later today.Furthermore, NOAA reports rainfall accumulations of 15 to 20 inches over portions of North Carolina, South Carolina and Mid-Atlantic states from late this week into early next week.Hurricane Florence set to be the most powerful hurricane to hit Carolinas in decades (Image: National Hurricane Center)The advisory read: &ldquoThis rainfall could produce catastrophic flash flooding and significant river flooding.A storm surge watch is in effect for Edisto Beach South Carolina to the North Carolina-Virginia border and Albemarle and Pamlico Sounds, including the Neuse and Pamlico Rivers.Classified as a Category 4 on the five-step Saffir-Simpson scale of hurricane strength, Florence is so far the most severe storm to threaten the US mainland this year and the first of its magnitude to target the Carolinas since 1989 when Hurricane Hugo barreled over Charleston, South Carolina.

title: European Union EU disintegrate Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras Brussels
story: (Image: During the financial crisis the EU, instead of becoming more democratic, became more technocratic)Mr Tsipras was responding to the annual &lsquostate of the union&rsquo address by EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker.He argued: &ldquoDuring the financial crisis the EU, instead of becoming more democratic, became more technocratic.&ldquoDecisions were taken behind closed doors in informal meets without a possibility of being responsible towards the citizens.As a result he warned the European Union could collapse in the face of pressure from populist and far-right forces.                Orban says Hungary will NOT yield to 'BLACKMAIL' of EU                 'Join the BREXIT CLUB!' Farage urges Orban to follow Britain OUT of EUHe said: &ldquoIn many crucial countries for the EU project the balance is becoming dangerous and this could lead to European disintegration.&ldquoThe European dream cannot be crushed between the destructive neoliberalism and the horrible far-right.In response Mr Tsipras claimed: &ldquoAll progressive, democratic and pro-European forces have a duty to stand side by side on the same side of history.Mr Tsipras was elected as the Greek Prime Minister in 2015 after vowing to end the austerity which was imposed after several Greek bailouts.Decisions were taken behind closed doors in informal meets (Image:  )However, despite initially standing up to Brussels, he ended up approving much of the austerity package which was overseen by the EU, European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund in the so-called &lsquotroika&rsquo.He attacked this in his European Parliament speech, saying: &ldquoWe had technocratic institutions like the troika who had the keys of economic sovereignty and were not responsible to anybody.However Mr Tsipras did emphasise that Greece remained committed to the EU.                Macron FEARS Brexit chaos will SPARK populist TAKEOVER of EU                 Former Eurocrat admits &lsquoEU do NOT have migration problem solution&rsquo&ldquoThe European dream cannot be crushed between the destructive neoliberalism and the far-right (Image:  )He said: &ldquoGreece and the Greeks have proven these last years that they are really deeply dedicated to the idea of European integration.&ldquoThey had to suffer a lot but they insisted on the European path despite the fact that some in Europe, in particularly the dominant, hurt our people.Greece finally exited its third EU bailout programme earlier this year.The Greek economy experienced the longest recession of any advanced capitalist economy (Image: )During its debt crisis, from 2009 to 2018, the Greek economy experienced the longest recession of any advanced capitalist economy, worse than the great depression in the US.Overall, the country lost around 25 percent of its GDP.Greece has parliamentary elections next year, with Mr Tsipras&rsquos left-wing Syriza party trailing its centre-right New Democracy rival in the polls.

title: brexit suspicion uk eu
story: He or she would wonder why on Earth all concerned are making such heavy weather of the Brexit talks.If ever, our Martian would argue, there were a negotiation set up to succeed, it is Brexit.After all, it is overwhelmingly in the interests of each side to bring the talks to a positive conclusion.What is more, thanks to Britain’s 45 years of EU membership, the two sides have the advantage of starting their new relationship with virtually identical rules and regulations.But what the Martian might not appreciate is that the Brexit talks are weighed down with baggage.Behind the sound and fury of these talks lies decades of misunderstanding and mutual suspicion.And there’s the rub.As a young member of the Foreign Office, I remember my relief when in the 1975 referendum two thirds of voters chose to stay in the European Community, as the European Union was then called.It was a terrible time in British life.The country was an economic mess, racked by inflation and strikes.Joining forces with Europe had offered us a way to reverse what seemed our unstoppable national decline.Like most British diplomats, I embraced it enthusiastically.In the 2016 referendum, I voted again to remain, but the passion was dead.In the intervening four decades too much had happened to curb my enthusiasm.In 1978 I was sent to Brussels to join the small army of British diplomats in our mission to the European Community.This was only three years after that first referendum.But already there was something wrong between us, the Brits, and the other eight member states.I could not put my finger on it.I mentioned this to an Italian friend, who worked in the European Commission.I have never forgotten his reply: “They will never forgive you for being the only country which was not invaded, occupied or defeated in the Second World War.”There were other things they did not forgive us for.Mrs Thatcher banged the table and, through sheer bloody-mindedness, secured a rebate on our contribution to the EU budget.We had a down-to-earth approach, which often clashed with the more flowery style of our European partners and trampled on their sensitivities.They rhapsodised about Ever Closer Union.We wanted the meetings to run punctually and reach practical conclusions.As time went by — a foretaste of today’s bitter struggle between Remainers and Leavers — British diplomats in Brussels would split between true believers in Europe’s mantra of Ever Closer Union and the pragmatists who saw EU membership as a vehicle for advancing the national interest.The irritation cut both ways.There was bad blood between us and the French from the start.We eventually joined the European Community in 1973.We had tried to join in 1961 and 1967, but had been blocked by the French president, General Charles de Gaulle, who famously twice said “Non” to Britain’s entry bid.We resented the assumption by France and Germany that they ran Europe, stitching up decisions between them in advance and seeking to impose them on everyone else.When I was ambassador in Germany in 1997, I heard Chancellor Helmut Kohl give a speech to his party faithful, the Christian Democrats.He was explaining to them why it was necessary to give up the national currency, the Deutsche mark, and replace it with the euro.This was an unpopular policy, which, had it gone to a referendum, would probably have been rejected.He told his audience that European integration and the euro were the price Germany had to pay, in his words, for dominating Europe without frightening its neighbours.Kohl went on to say that the euro would be no less strong or stable than the Deutsche mark.This was a pledge of special importance to the legion of small German savers.It is a pledge which ever since has forced the member states of the eurozone to march to the beat of the German economy, with disastrous consequences for weaker economies including Greece and Italy.Of course there are aspects of the Brexit negotiations which are complicated and take time to sort out.But there is also a burden of history that weighs them down.More and more I have come to the conclusion that de Gaulle was right. It was the General — not arch-Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg — who commented that Britain had “very marked and very original habits and traditions”.It is those traditions which make us unfit for membership of the EU.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may must think about brexit 2019
story: Between attempting to get a deal that works for Britain and preparing for a No Deal if Brussels bureaucrats remain so inflexible, there is PLENTY of work to do over the coming months.Thinking about four years’ time is an unnecessary distraction.For one thing she needs to insist that her civil servants — and some of her Cabinet colleagues — get with the programme. Many of them need to listen to Sir Christopher Meyer, a former Remainer who is now looking forward to a brighter future free of the EU’s iron grip.It is crucial that everybody involved in these next vital months of negotiations is genuinely ambitious about what Britain can be as a truly independent country.We have the fifth-largest economy in the world and we’re a “soft-power” titan.There might be people in Brussels who think we are doomed to failure once we leave — but there shouldn’t be any ­sitting on our side of the table.If the Government prepares us properly for a clean break over the coming months, we’ve no reason to be scared for the future. It will strengthen our hand in negotiations, too.So get on with THAT, Prime Minister.THE Russian bear is roaring, and we don’t seem ready to defend ourselves.Today a respected intelligence expert suggests our border control could have been hacked by Russian spies in the run-up to the Salisbury attack.The Prime Minister has been admirably tough with the Kremlin, even if Jeremy Corbyn and other useful idiots have attempted to undermine her and our ­national security at every turn.But there is no room for complacency. There are serious concerns that our defence budget isn’t sufficient — and that the Treasury is worried the MoD wouldn’t know what to do with any additional cash.We are in a digital war and we cannot afford to lose it.THE feelgood factor from England’s World Cup campaign keeps on going.As if uniting the country for those few weeks wasn’t enough­, the players have donated their match fees to charity.It’s true to say they won’t miss the cash but it’s a gesture that sums up this new England team.Well played, lads.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit lifeline theresa may michel barnier
story: The remaining member states are set to add to the guidelines issued to their chief negotiator in a sign British warnings about “no deal” are finally hitting home.Speaking at a forum in Slovenia this afternoon, Mr Barnier said: “I think if we are realistic we are able to reach an agreement on the first stage of the work - which is the Brexit treaty - within six to eight weeks.“We must reach an agreement by the beginning of November.”The EU chief negotiator’s unusually upbeat remarks came as Labour peer Lord Mandelson claimed the EU was mounting a “Save Theresa” operation.Devout Remainer Mandy says Brussels fears a collapse in talks would bring down Theresa May.He added: “They don’t want Boris Johnson — they think he would plunge Britain, and to a certain extent Europe, into chaos.And the Prime Ministers hopes of securing a deal were further bolstered by Austrian leader Sebastian Kurz, who has told Eurocrats to up their game in the talks.The Chancellor, whose country holds the rotating presidency of the bloc, said he wants concrete progress within weeks and called for new thinking.EU leaders will meet in Salzburg later this month, where Mr Barnier will give an update on the negotiations over a lunch dedicated to unsticking negotiations.Speaking about the summit, Mr Kurz said: I hope were able to make some progress on Brexit.It would be good if in Salzburg we already had a Commission proposal for finding an agreement with Britain this Autumn.The Austrian is understood to be determined to wrap up a deal on the Withdrawal Agreement before the end of his countrys presidency in December.And sources told the FT new wording will be handed to Mr Barnier to “serve as a sort of mandate to do the deal” in response to repeated pleas from the UK.But they stressed member states remain completely behind Mr Barnier and that the alteration would largely be an act of symbolism.EU diplomats have also cautioned that the move may not provide as much of a boost for Mrs May as she is hoping for.One warned The Sun: Engaging per se doesnt mean good or bad for the UK. I wouldnt necessarily interpret it as helping May.However, the news was welcomed by Eurosceptics who have repeatedly called on Member States to pressurise the hard-line Commission to compromise.Henry Newman, director of the Open Europe think tank and a former advisor to Michael Gove, said: This is long overdue.The EUs only offer is a trade agreement for just Great Britain, essentially annexing Northern Ireland in a separate regulatory and customs regime. Impossible.Even if he is, Theresa May must not follow suit.The Chequers offer is already so over-generous it has triggered Cabinet resignations and Tory mutiny. If Barnier now wants to make it work for fear of a No Deal, it is a signal for us to realise the EU is on the back foot and to extract more concessions.Mrs May must not give an inch over free movement or anything else. Nor commit a penny of our divorce bill without tying it to a decent deal.It would be fatal for her. Chequers looks almost dead as it is. Even if Barnier breathes life into it, many Tories are still vowing to vote it down.Barnier has been overplaying his hand for two years. The EU is waking up to it, possibly too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
